newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Zambia police search opposition leader's house.
newsitem.headline: Zambia police search opposition leader's house.

text.p: Zambian police on Thursday briefly held an opposition leader and searched his house in a continued crackdown on politicians who refuse to recognise President Frederick Chiluba's government after controversial elections.
Witnesses said Liberal Progressive Front chairman Rodger Chongwe was picked up from his office in the morning and interrogated before police ransacked his house.
"They say they are looking for a letter my husband wrote to Southern African Development Community (SADC) heads of state on the elections," Chongwe's wife, Gwenda, told reporters during the search.
"I have told them that they will not find it because I flushed it down the toilet," she added.

Chongwe, who leads an alliance of opposition parties that boycotted November's elections, wrote to SADC leaders last month, warning of a possible military takeover if they did not step in to resolve the country's political crisis.

The parties have rejected the results of the November 18 elections, which they claim were rigged by Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD). They say they will lead a disobedience campaign to unseat the Chiluba government.
Several opposition leaders, including former president Kenneth Kaunda, watched police searching Chongwe's house.
"This is disgusting. It is nothing but harrassment of opposition leaders," Kaunda said.
The former president challenged police to arrest him: "I co-authored the letter to the SADC leaders. Why don't you arrest me as well?" he asked.
Police ended their three-hour search without confiscating any property.
Chongwe is the second opposition leader to have faced police action since the polls.
Zambia Democratic Congress leader Dean Mungomba went into hiding last week after police tried to arrest him for warning his party would resist the Chiluba government with violence.
